H0.text: Cooling temperatures is the process by which an igneous rock forms in the rock cycle.

H1.text: High pressure and heat are the conditions from which an igneous rock forms in the rock cycle.

H2.text: Weathering and erosion form igneous rocks in the rock cycle.

H3.text: Compacted plant remains are the material from which an igneous rock forms in the rock cycle.

A4.text: Igneous rocks are formed through the cooling and solidification of magma or lava.

A5.text: The melting is caused by one or more of three processes: an increase in temperature, a decrease in pressure, or a change in composition.

A6.text: If the conditions no longer exist for the magma to stay in its liquid state, it cools and solidifies into an igneous rock.

A7.text: Weathering and erosion break the original rock down into smaller fragments and carry away dissolved material.

A8.text: The addition of carbon dioxide is relatively a much less important cause of magma formation than the addition of water.

A9.text: Decompression melting occurs because of a decrease in pressure. It is the most important mechanism for producing magma from the upper mantle.
